title: Loukoumades Recipe
description: This loukoumades recipe makes yeast-risen dough puffs that are deep-fried until golden brown, drizzled with honey syrup, and sprinkled with cinnamon.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines European Greek Loukoumades 4.7 (39) 26 Reviews 9 Photos Loukoumades are fried Greek honey puffs. They're popular all around the Mediterranean, especially in Greece, and are beloved as a Hanukkah treat among Sephardic Jews. Submitted by JOANNA Updated on December 6, 2023 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 9 9 9 9 Prep Time: 10 mins Cook Time: 15 mins Additional Time: 1 hr 5 mins Total Time: 1 hr 30 mins Servings: 25 Yield: 25 loukoumades Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 25 servings 2 (.25 ounce) packages active dry yeast 1 cup warm water, no more than 100 degrees F (40 degrees C) ½ cup warm milk ¼ cup white sugar 1 teaspoon salt 4 cups all-purpose flour 3 large eggs ⅓ cup butter, softened ½ cup honey ½ cup water 4 cups vegetable oil, or as needed 2 teaspoons ground cinnamon Directions Sprinkle yeast over 1 cup warm water in a small bowl. Let stand until yeast softens and begins to form a creamy foam, about 5 minutes. Mix together warm milk, sugar, and salt in a large bowl until sugar and salt are dissolved. Pour in yeast mixture and stir to combine. Beat in flour, eggs, and butter until mixture forms a smooth, soft dough. Cover the bowl and let rise at room temperature until doubled in volume, about 30 minutes. Stir dough well, cover, and let rise again for 30 more minutes. Meanwhile, mix together honey and 1/2 cup water in a small saucepan; bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Turn off the heat and allow honey syrup to cool. Heat 2 inches oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Place a large serving or soup spoon in a glass of water near dough. Scoop up about 2 tablespoons dough per puff with the wet spoon, drop it into the wet palm of your hand, and roll it back into the spoon to create a round shape. Do not overhandle the puffy, soft dough. Drop dough balls into hot oil in batches, wetting the spoon each time you make a dough ball. Fry in hot oil until golden brown on the bottom, then roll them over to cook the other side, 2 to 3 minutes per batch. Gently set loukoumades aside to drain on a paper towel-lined plate. Place loukoumades on a baking sheet. Drizzle with honey syrup and sprinkle with cinnamon. Serve warm. I Made It Print 81 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 167 Calories 7g Fat 24g Carbs 3g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 25 Calories 167 % Daily Value * Total Fat 7g 9% Saturated Fat 2g 12% Cholesterol 29mg 10% Sodium 122mg 5% Total Carbohydrate 24g 9% Dietary Fiber 1g 3% Total Sugars 8g Protein 3g 6% Vitamin C 0mg 0% Calcium 16mg 1% Iron 1mg 7% Potassium 53mg 1% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Loukoumades 01 of 09 Photo by  Meredith Food Studios 02 of 09 Photo by  GlitzyTart7302 01/08/2024 OK with tweaks This was really tasty. It was very fluffy on the inside and had a nice thin crisp on the outside. There’s only a few things that I’d personally change. I had it with and without the honey cinnamon glaze, it’s not so great. The water made the honey very runny, I think the one to one requirement was a bit much. I had some left over rum & butter sauce, it was fantastic together with the loukoumades, with some ice cream it was just wow!If you love the idea of honey, maybe you’d be better off just warming the honey without water or with some butter.Also the recipe produces a very large quantity, I was able to make 30 fist sized spheres. If it’s just you and three other people, you may want to half the recipe. 03 of 09 Photo by  Jacolyn 06/30/2021 My family is Greek-American, and though this was my first time making these, I’ve had them many times before. The dough is delicious, and the honey syrup was perfect (though next time I’ll dunk them in the syrup a bit instead of just drizzling it as I prefer soaked loukoumades). Shaping them took some practice. I originally made mine too big and not perfectly round, but by the end they were the way I like them. I did dip the spoon in oil instead of water. And to shape them, I took a cue from a video on YouTube to perfect the process of grabbing the dough with one hand, squeezing out a small ball between my index finger and thumb, and then using the oiled spoon to cut/scoop it away neatly for the oil. I’ll definitely be making these again. 04 of 09 Photo by  Faith N 06/27/2021 These were pretty good. I had to cut down the amount to cook to 1 tbsp, as they started burning before fully cooked through at 2 tbsp. I found the syrup too thin, so we just drizzled them with honey and cinnamon directly. 05 of 09 Photo by  Stacey Ann 06/07/2020 06 of 09 Photo by  Jenna Falk 05/31/2020 Omg. Just omg. Added some brown sugar and corn starch to make the sauce thicker. It made about 80-100 balls for me wow! Might cut recipe in half next time. 07 of 09 Photo by  Baker of Cakes 05/28/2018 Definitely tasted good. I followed some suggestions in the comments to add the cinnamon and some sugar to the honey syrup, then let them soak in it. I would suggest using maybe half a teaspoon to a whole teaspoon of dough per puff; mine puffed up big while frying. It also made so many that it took me 2 hours just to fry them all 0.0 08 of 09 Photo by  Brenna 11/12/2016 09 of 09 Photo by  ashpip 02/15/2010 1 You’ll Also Love Greek Garbanzo Bean Salad 580 Ratings Authentic Mandelbrot 5 Ratings Rugelach with Cream Cheese Filling 12 Ratings Chanukah Cookies 26 Ratings Scandinavian Snowflake Cookies 2 Ratings Easy Greek Salad 683 Ratings Best Ever Rugelach 13 Ratings Ali's Greek Tortellini Salad 277 Ratings Greek Green Beans 187 Ratings Aunt Martha's Jewish Coffee Cake 6 Ratings Amazing Passover Chocolate Toffee Matzo 21 Ratings Soft, Chewy Rosh Hashanah Honey-Walnut Cookies 17 Ratings Curried Sweet Potato Latkes 29 Ratings Gyros Burgers 295 Ratings Orzo and Tomato Salad with Feta Cheese 276 Ratings Drozdzowka (Polish Yeast Plum Cake) 8 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: JOANNA
instructions: Sprinkle yeast over 1 cup warm water in a small bowl. Let stand until yeast softens and begins to form a creamy foam, about 5 minutes.;Mix together warm milk, sugar, and salt in a large bowl until sugar and salt are dissolved. Pour in yeast mixture and stir to combine.;Beat in flour, eggs, and butter until mixture forms a smooth, soft dough. Cover the bowl and let rise at room temperature until doubled in volume, about 30 minutes. Stir dough well, cover, and let rise again for 30 more minutes.;Meanwhile, mix together honey and 1/2 cup water in a small saucepan; bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Turn off the heat and allow honey syrup to cool.;Heat 2 inches oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).;Place a large serving or soup spoon in a glass of water near dough. Scoop up about 2 tablespoons dough per puff with the wet spoon, drop it into the wet palm of your hand, and roll it back into the spoon to create a round shape. Do not overhandle the puffy, soft dough.;Drop dough balls into hot oil in batches, wetting the spoon each time you make a dough ball. Fry in hot oil until golden brown on the bottom, then roll them over to cook the other side, 2 to 3 minutes per batch. Gently set loukoumades aside to drain on a paper towel-lined plate.;Place loukoumades on a baking sheet. Drizzle with honey syrup and sprinkle with cinnamon. Serve warm.
